free_text.Content: The course first introduces basic concepts, such as utility and inter-temporal utility maximization that form the basis of macroeconomic models. Then it introduces macroeconomic models relevant for the analysis of short-run fluctuations, interest rate determination, monetary policy, foreign exchange rates, etc.  Students will learn how to solve and simulate these models.[br/][br/]The course will cover the following topics:[br/][li] National income accounting and the business cycle[br/][li]Utility functions[br/][li]A simple two-period model with consumption, investment and firms[br/][li]The optimal growth model and dynamic programming[br/][li]The stochastic growth model with flexible labor supply[br/][li]Competitive equilibrium with complete markets[br/][li]Consumption and asset pricing
free_text.Type of teaching: Lectures. Exercise sessions will take place in a classroom equipped with computers.
free_text.Learning outcomes: This course provides students with a working knowledge of macroeconomic models that explicitly incorporate financial markets. These models and concepts underlie many of the mathematical and financial tools that are introduced later in the program.
